sections.title: Intro Scenario
sections.text: The town of Greenview is holding a public hearing to discuss a new **zoning ordinance**. The **zoning ordinance** proposed zoning an unused chunk of land on the edge of town to residential use to accommodate a growing population.

sections.title: Question 1
sections.text: What new thing is being discussed at the public hearing?

sections.title: Explanation
sections.text: A **zoning ordinance** is a government regulation that controls how land can be used in a specific area. It’s enacted by municipalities, such as cities or counties, under their police powers to ensure orderly development and protect public welfare. That’s why, in the story, Greenview held a public hearing to decide whether farm land could be re-zoned for residential use. Public hearings are a key part of creating zoning ordinances—they give the community a chance to voice concerns and provide input.

sections.title: Story Continued
sections.text: During the discussion, the city planner explained that the ordinance would create a Buffer Zone of trees and open land between the new neighborhood and the remaining farmland.

sections.title: Question 2
sections.text: What would be contained within the buffer zone, and what would it separate?

sections.title: Answer 2
sections.text: The buffer zone would contain trees and open land, separating the new neighborhood and the remaining farmland zones.
